title: Active Living Research Tools and Measures
purpose: Active Living Research offers a range of tools and resources to help practitioners, policy-makers, and advocates create more activity-friendly environments.  Measures assess schools, parks, streets, and other neighborhood settings to see how well they support physical activity.
keywords: Motor Activity ||  Physical Fitness ||  Exercise ||  Community Health Planning ||  Questionnaires
description: Three types of tools are available:  observational tools to assess the environment;  observational tools to assess physical activity;  surveys to assess perceptions of the environment.

title: Irvine Minnesota Inventory
purpose: Understanding the impact of the built environment on physical activity levels requires reliable methods to measure potentially relevant built environment features. The Irvine Minnesota Inventory was designed to measure a wide range of built environment features that are potentially linked to active living, especially walking.
keywords: Bicycling ||  City Planning ||  Environment Design ||  Health Behavior ||  Public Health ||  Residence Characteristics ||  Walking
description: The Irvine Minnesota inventory includes 160 items, which cover four domains: accessibility (62 items), pleasurability (56 items), perceived safety from traffic (31 items), and perceived safety from crime (15 items). The inventory includes both a paper version and a version in Microsoft Access, to allow data to be input into the computer directly. The items in the inventory were tested for inter-rater reliability in both southern California and the Minneapolis - St. Paul metropolitan area.
reliability: The items in the inventory were tested for inter-rater reliability in both southern California and the Minneapolis - St. Paul metropolitan area. Inter-rater reliability was high, with 77 percent of the items attaining 80% agreement or better in both southern California and Minnesota reliability tests.

title: Path Environment Audit Tool
keywords: Environment Design ||  Exercise ||  Health Behavior ||  Leisure Activities ||  Residence Characteristics ||  Safety
description: To determine how physical characteristics of trails may influence use, reliable and valid audit tools are needed. The Path Environment Audit Tool (PEAT) was developed with design, amenity, and aesthetics/maintenance items. Two observers independently audited 185 trail segments at 6 Massachusetts facilities. GPS-derived items were used as a "gold standard." Kappa (k) statistics, observed agreement and ICCs were calculated to assess inter-observer reliability and validity. Fifteen of 16 primary amenity items had k-values > 0.49 ("moderate") and all had observed agreement > 81%. Seven binary design items had k-values ranging from 0.19 to 0.69 and three of 5 ordinal items had ICCs > 0.52. Only two aesthetics/maintenance items (n=7) had moderate ICCs. Observed agreement between PEAT and GPS items was > 0.77; k-values were > 0.57 for 7 out of 10 comparisons. PEAT has acceptable inter-observer reliability and validity for most of its primary items and appears ready for use by researchers and practitioners.

title: Pedestrian Environment Data Scan Tool
purpose: The audit instrument was designed to specifically address pedestrian concerns as well as minimize cost and implementation time. An electronic (palmOS) version of the audit is available, as are extensive training materials.
keywords: Environment Design ||  Walking
description: The PEDS instrument was developed to measure environmental features that relate to walking in varied environments in the US. It is an adaptation of Terri Pikora’s SPACES to the US environment, focusing solely on the pedestrian environment.

title: Computerized Adaptive Test - Mental Health
purpose: Adaptive Testing Technologies (ATT) designs, tests, and implements Computerized Adaptive tests for depression, substance abuse, suicidality, anxiety and mania/hypomania (CAT-MH).
keywords:
Anxiety Disorders ||  Bipolar Disorder ||  Depressive Disorder, Major ||  Diagnosis, Computer-Assisted ||  

Psychiatric Status Rating Scales
description: CAT-MH is a new approach to CAT using a bi-factor multidimensional IRT model and derived a new item information function (IIF) that can be used in item selection. Results for the depression test reveal that the information in a 400 item depression bank can be efficiently extracted using an average of 12 items per patient (in 2 minutes) while maintaining a correlation of r=0.95 with the 400 item test results.

title: K-CAT
keywords: Adolescent ||  Child ||  Bipolar Disorder ||  Depression ||  Psychiatric Status Rating Scales
description: K-CAT, the children’s version of CAT-MH, has been validated for youth ages 7-17. The K-CAT includes self-rated and parent-rated modules for: depression, anxiety, mania/hypomania, ADHD, conduct disorder, oppositional defiant disorder and suicidality. The information contained in 1867 items can be adaptively extracted from both the child and parent in 7 minutes and reproduces the results of clinical structured diagnostic interviews (KSADS) with unprecedentedly high precision and accuracy.

title: Assessing Bedside Bar-Coding Readiness
source: Agency For Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
purpose: This tool will help hospitals better understand what is required to apply this emerging technology in health care and to prepare for implementation of a bedside bar-coded drug administration system. The materials will help organizations understand the issues related to bar coding in health care, assess their readiness, and move towards an effective implementation.
related_tools: Leading a Strategic Planning Effort;  Looking Collectively at Risk
keywords: Technology ||   Bar-coding ||   Drug Administration ||  Implementation ||  Medication Errors
description: A multidisciplinary panel of health care experts and leaders has collaborated to develop three new educational tools for reducing medication errors. Each tool addresses a discrete organizational component: strategic planning, risk assessment, and information technology. Used together, the tools provide hospitals with a process for making fundamental, wide-ranging improvements to their medication delivery systems. Using the results of a landmark Medication Safety Self Assessment survey of over 1,400 hospitals, the Pathways team prototyped three tools. The prototypes were shared with participating hospitals whose feedback was incorporated into the ultimate design of the tools. By sharing their experience and expertise, participating hospitals ensured that the tools would reflect road-tested, practical methods for making improvements in medication safety. These resulting tools provide hospitals with a process to: 1.Incorporate medication safety initiatives into their strategic plans. 2. Perform an organization-wide risk assessment to identify areas for improvement. 3. Assess the organization's readiness to implement a bar-coding system for administering medications.   Data collected in the Institute for Safe Medication Practices Medication Safety Self Assessment (2000) provided some important facts about U.S. hospitals: *43% can easily access essential patient information.*53% can easily access drug information.*46% have standardized safe methods for communicating medication orders.*48% include patients as an active partner through effective education.*41% have instituted simple redundancies for critical medications, patients,and processes.*46% have established a nonpunitive,system-based approach to medication error reduction. These findings underscore the need to make fundamental changes in the ways that medications are packaged, ordered, stored, prescribed, and administered.
reference: Scan if you can. HIMSS News. 14(1):January 2003. Pg 5     F.D.A. Requires Bar Codes on Drugs, New York Times, March 14, 2003.

title: Bioterrorism Emergency Planning and Preparedness Questionnaire for Healthcare Facilities
source: Agency For Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
purpose: The Bioterrorism Initiative of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) supports research in assessing and improving the U.S. health care system's capacity to respond to possible incidents of bioterrorism. The initiative examines the preparedness of the frontline staff as well as linkages between these health care components and local and State public health departments and emergency responders.    The purpose of the AHRQ project "Understanding Needs for Health System Preparedness and Capacity for Bioterrorist Attacks" was to develop and pilot test tools to assess the current capacity of hospitals and health systems to respond to a bioterrorist attack. Focusing on two large university and two community hospitals, the project used a data collection tool, model criteria, and a simulation and analysis model.
keywords: Bioterrorism || Civil Defense ||  Disaster Planning ||  Health Care Surveys ||  Health Facilities ||  Organizational Policy ||    Questionnaires

title: CAHPS American Indian Survey
source: Agency For Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
purpose: The CAHPS American Indian Survey asks American Indians about their experiences with health care facilities.
keywords: Consumer Participation ||      Health Care Surveys ||  Indians ||  North American ||    Patient Satisfaction ||  Professional-Patient Relations ||    Quality of Health Care ||    Questionnaires ||  United States Indian Health Service ||  Patient-Reported Outcomes ||  Patient Reported Outcomes ||  PROs
description: The American Indian Survey is a standardized questionnaire for adult American Indians. It was originally developed for the Choctaw Nation Health Service but has been adapted for use by other tribal nations.

title: CAHPS Child Hospital Survey
source: Agency For Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
purpose: The CAHPS Child Hospital Survey (Child HCAHPS) assesses the experiences of pediatric patients (17 and younger) and their parents or guardians with inpatient care. It complements the Adult Hospital Survey, which asks adult inpatients about their experiences. Child HCAHPS covers most of the topics addressed by the Adult version of the Hospital Survey as well as topics that are particularly relevant to pediatric care.  It was developed by the Center of Excellence for Pediatric Quality Measurement at Boston Children’s Hospital in partnership with AHRQ’s CAHPS Consortium.
keywords: Adolescent ||    Child ||    Child ||  Preschool ||    Health Status ||  Hospitals ||    Infant ||    Infant ||  Newborn ||    Patient Satisfaction ||  Patient-Reported Outcomes ||  Patient Reported Outcomes ||  PROs
description: The main purpose of the Child Hospital Survey is to address the need to assess and improve the experiences of pediatric inpatients and their parents. Like other CAHPS surveys, this questionnaire focuses on aspects of pediatric inpatient care that are important to patients and their parents, and for which patients and their parents are generally the best source of information. The survey results are expected to be useful to everyone with a need for information on the quality of pediatric inpatient care, including patients, parents, hospitals, health plans, insurers, and policy makers.      The Child Hospital Survey produces 18 measures of patient experience: 10 composite measures and 8 single-item measures, including an overall rating of the hospital. Composite measures combine two or more survey questions that are statistically and conceptually related.

title: CAHPS Clinician & Group Surveys
source: Agency For Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
purpose: The Clinician & Group Surveys (CG-CAHPS) assess patients' experiences with health care providers and staff in doctor’s offices.
population: Adults and children ages 18 and younger. Clinician practice and medical groups
keywords: Academic Medical Centers ||    Health Care Surveys ||  Patient Satisfaction ||  Questionnaires ||  Patient-Reported Outcomes ||  Patient Reported Outcomes ||  PROs ||  Social Determinants of Health
description: To ensure that survey results are comparable across users, every CAHPS Clinician & Group Survey starts with a set of “core” items that everyone uses. (The surveys for children have some additional core items that address preventive and developmental care.) Users can then customize their survey by adding supplemental items.     While the surveys are designed for patients with insurance coverage from commercial plans, Medicaid, or Medicare, the Clinician & Group Surveys are not administered by type of insurance coverage. Survey sponsors may also use it to learn about the experiences of patients who are uninsured.    Multiple versions of the CAHPS Clinician & Group Survey are available to meet users' needs:    12-Month Survey: Asks patients to report on their experiences with their provider over the last 12 months. The National Quality Forum endorsed this survey in July 2007.  Expanded 12-Month Survey with Patient-Centered Medical Home (PCMH) Item Set: Asks patients to report on their experiences with primary care providers over the last 12 months. This expanded survey addresses a broader set of topics by incorporating the Patient-Centered Medical Home Item Set into the 12-Month Survey.  Visit Survey: Asks patients to report on their experiences with their provider at a recent visit. Only questions about getting access to care refer to the last 12 months.
pop_racial: American Indian or Alaska Native; Asian ; Black or African American; White ; Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander; All
pop_ethnic: Hispanic  or  Latino;Not Hispanic  or  Latino
variables: Getting timely appointments, care and information; how well providers (or doctors) communicate with patients; helpful,  courteous, and respectful office staff; patients’ rating of the provider (or doctor).
special_notes: Results are reported annually
reference: Compendium of Publicly Available Datasets and Other Data-Related Resources.        The National Partnership for Action to End Health Disparities has compiled a Compendium of Publicly Available Datasets and Other Data-Related Resources (Compendium).  This free resource details publicly available data relevant to research and programs aiming to reduce health disparities. The Compendium compiles in one place descriptions of and links to public datasets and resources that include information about health conditions and other factors that impact the health of minority populations.        https://www.minorityhealth.hhs.gov/NPA/Materials/FIHET_Data_Compendium_508_version_FINAL_11_28_2016.pdf

title: CAHPS Cultural Competence Item Set
source: Agency For Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
purpose: The CAHPS Cultural Competence Item Set is designed to capture the patient's perspective on the cultural competence of health care providers. Culturally competent care is defined as care that is responsive to diversity in the patient population and cultural factors that can affect health and health care, such as language, communication styles, beliefs, attitudes, and behaviors.
keywords: Attitude of Health Personnel ||    Communication ||    Cultural Competency ||  Health Care Surveys ||      Patient Participation ||    Patient Satisfaction ||    Physician-Patient Relations ||  Prejudice ||    Reproducibility of Results ||    Socioeconomic Factors ||  PROs ||  Patient-Reported Outcomes ||  Patient Reported Outcomes
description: Topics Covered by the Cultural Competence Item Set:    The Cultural Competence Item Set covers the following topics:    Patient-provider communication;   Complementary and alternative medicine;   Experiences of discrimination due to race/ethnicity, insurance, or language;   Experiences leading to trust or distrust, including level of trust, caring and truth-telling;   Linguistic competency (Access to language services).    Quality Measures from the Cultural Competence Item Set:    Users of this item set can calculate and report two composite measures:    Providers (Doctors) are polite and considerate;   Providers (Doctors) are caring and inspire trust;   * Note: This composite measure is intended to supplement the existing composite measure for doctor communication. (How well doctors communicate with patients), which can be calculated from the core items in the Clinician & Group Surveys.    The remaining questions in the item set cannot be rolled up into composite measures.

title: CAHPS Dental Plan Survey
source: Agency For Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
purpose: The CAHPS Dental Plan Survey asks patients to report on their experiences with care and services from a dental plan, the dentists, and their staff.
keywords: Consumer Behavior ||  Dentist-Patient Relations ||    Health Care ||  Quality of Health Care ||  Patient-Reported Outcomes ||  Patient Reported Outcomes ||  PROs
description: The Dental Plan Survey asks adult enrollees in dental plans about their experiences with the plan, the dentists, and their staff. This survey was originally developed for the TRICARE dental plan, but has been adapted for other uses.    The CAHPS Dental Plan Survey is being used to evaluate dental programs that cover about 3 million lives. It is available for use by States, purchasers, and other organizations interested in assessing, improving, and reporting on the quality and value offered by dental plans.    No supplemental items were developed for this survey.
